name: Customer.io
service: a rules-based email tool to help companies grow
description: At Customer.io, I was the first employee, V.P. of Product and lead front-end developer writing Ember.js, HTML and CSS/Sass. I formed product principles, worked with the co-founders to prioritize features, conducted user research, designed mock-up for many complicated flows, and implemented the front-end code. While I was at the company, Customer.io grew from 10 customers earning $100 a month to 330 customers earning $50,000 a month in 1.5 years.

name: Venmo
description: At Venmo, I started the process of redesigning the new app. I conducted extensive user research and developed mock-ups to answer the following questions: What is the deepest need we are serving? What are our critical product features? What are barriers to adoption? I found that 1) people didn't understand the full range of use cases and 2) people found it difficult to sign up their friends. I prototyped and tested a new app that addressed these concerns. New app to hit the market soon!

name: MoveTogether
description: Ridesharing is a difficult two-sided, supply-driven market problem. It's hard to incentivize drivers to offer a ride as they prize convenience and their quiet, personal time. However, ridesharing was more successful amongst close-knit communities. Therefore, my team pivoted to a one-sided market: taxi-sharing amongst the business community. We prototyped at the GoogleI/0 conference in 2011, matching rides to and from SFO. It was a big success.

name: Yiftee
description: Small business owners are incredibly busy and have difficult-to-integrate POSs. They do not have time to analyze rich customer data or train employees on new offerings. Their bottom-line is their major concern. Therefore, my team pivoted from an initial customer data product to a digital gift-giving service that was much lower touch and had a more direct impact on revenue. Check out Yiftee!

name: National Grocery Chain
description: This Canadian national grocery chain was experiencing declining pharmacy sales. My team designed and conducted a consumer research program consisting of an online survey, customer interviews, shop-alongs and focus groups to better understand the problem. The number one driver of loyalty seemed to be superior pharmacists and customer care. We put together a plan to better train pharmacists and to automate pharmacy processes so pharmacists can spend more time with patients.

name: Global Pharmaceutical
description: This livestock pharmaceutical company realized that their complementary husbandry services were actually incredibly useful for farmers. Therefore, my team helped implement an innovative new business model: livestock preventative care and education services. I collaborated closely with the client to develop educator training materials and prove the business case for this business.

name: Canadian Telecom
description: A regional Canadian Telco was looking to expand nationally. We assessed user needs and the potential economic viability of various segments - the Chinese immigrant population, college students, cab drivers and the elderly. For each segment, we prototyped relevant product features based on user research, and presented ideas to leadership for implementation.

name: Sigma-Dek
description: People desire the emotional satisfaction of building a deck themselves instead of contracting it out. But they want to be able to build the deck in a weekend and without many obscure tools. Therefore, the team tested the concept of a simple-assembly deck: pieces snap together, but are still stable, safe and strong, and the entire deck can be built in 45 minutes. This deck is now sold across North America.

name: Marketing White Paper
description: This was a re-look at the traditional advertising mantra: market, media, message. We advocated that effective global brands also consider "moment": When are users most receptive? How can in-store experiences be designed to make emotional connections with customers?

name: Legal Services Company
description: An emerging trend in the legal services market at the time was the use of semantic-based search for the discovery process. Semantic-based search yields results based on meaning rather than simple text matching so lawyers can find more relevant results. We recommended that our client enter this space through an acquisition and focus resources in this area.

name: Gmail Analysis
description: We spend so much of our time and interaction on email now! I wrote an R package that downloads a user's email history, conducts text analysis and graphs results. What time of day are you most likely to reply to an email? What day of week? How many emails do you send per day?

name: SplitMyRide
description: I wrote all the server-side code for a taxi-sharing service that matches people taking cabs from New York airports to Manhattan / Brooklyn.

name: Instagram Challenge
description: I lost sense of time in this Instagram Engineering Challenge. The task was to make a shredded and scrambled image look normal.

name: Venmo
description: In my final 3 weeks at Venmo, I picked up android programming as it was a high need at the time. I deployed some new features including payment sharing and foursquare connect. I also squashed a lot of bugs.

name: Search Algorithm
description: The purpose of this project was to build two different search algorithms, term-at-a-time and document-at-a-time, and compare their efficiency. Term-at-a-time is optimal for shorter, rare query terms, while doc-at-a-time is preferred for longer and more frequent queries.

name: DrinksOnMe
description: This is a foursquare-venmo mash-up that allows you to buy a drink for anyone checked-in to the same location as you. Basically a pick-up tool for the shy geek in some of us. I helped the Venmo team build this by contributing to the android code.

name: pod
description: This web app pulls and displays photos from a flickr account that were taken on today's date in any previous year.

name: National Cable Provider
description: In the past, decisions at this company had largely been driven by the instinct and intuition of leadership. With the changing landscape in media, the company needed to better understand their customers and product lines in a quantitative way. Therefore, my team developed a customer-life-time value model to identify high-profit and low-profit customers, which customers are worth trying to keep, and what product lines are associated with lowest churn.

name: Global Pharmaceutical
description: The client needed a tool to forecast uptake and profits for a new drug. I built a war-game simulation model to understand 36 month growth under various indication and competitor launch scenarios.

name: Resume 2.0
description: I have a personal mission to help people love what they do for a living. The first step to landing your dream job is to articulate and present your story in a beautiful, concise and provocative way. Traditional Word resumes don't cut it anymore (especially, if you are gunning for a job in tech). So, if you are looking for a job and like this site, get in touch with me. I'll help you.

name: YogaProject
description: I made this series of yoga videos for friends in Asia, where unfortunately good yoga classes are not readily available.

name: Mzcombozi Secondary
description: I taught math to 40 Eighth Grade students who sat in 20 desks. The thrill of seeing their faces when a concept clicked is still one of the greatest moments in my life. I had to do a lot of laundry during those 5 weeks because I typically came home covered in chalk dust.

name: CatchPhrase
description: My first arduino hack! A user presses a button to randomly display a phrase from a previously programmed list on an LCD screen -- a good tool for charades and studying.

name: Splash
description: I taught kids in East Palo Alto an hour long seminar on "Things I wish I learned when I was your age". Topics included how to make decisions, how to deal with feedback in work and relationships, and an introduction to cognitive heuristics we all have to watch out for.
